items.title: 2023 Running Plans üèÉ
items.content_html:
I’m planning on running a full marathon in 2024.

I’ve been planning for this since I started training for the half marathon I just ran. I looked at the half marathon as a chance to dip my toe in the distance-running water to see whether I liked the feel for this kind of training or whether it felt like too much. So far, so good: nothing about the half marathon cycle I just went through made me want to give up.

It’s funny, because even with what I’ve done, I still feel like I have a little imposter syndrome, when it comes to running. I still feel very conservative in my approach, using the word “training” still kind of makes me want to break out in hives, and I come into this knowing that running a full marathon isn’t some huge life-long dream of mine. (For that, you’d have to look at biking. While I’ve biked one metric century, I still feel like I’ve got at least one full 100 mile ride in me. Some day.) I started running three years ago in order to support a particular charity 5k, and with two kids in the house I was looking for a form of exercise that was a bit more effective than bicycling (which long rides, when I was training for that metric century, took me out of the house forrrevvvver), and because I generally thought it would be cool to be able to run a full mile without stopping. After a couple rocky years I got more consistent with running last year and started wondering if I could run a marathon.

And I started to think that maybe I could. And I started to think that maybe if I thought I could, if I even had an inkling of interest in it, maybe I should do something about it sooner rather than later, because while I’m not old, I’m certainly not getting any younger. At one point I thought about just going straight for it in 2023 but then decided I’m just not that hardcore. So I came up with a loose plan to give myself well over a year to build up to it while also giving myself plenty of freedom to back out at any time for any reason with no penalty.

And now here I am, my first half marathon in the books, and as of right now, that big-picture goal still seems reasonable. I mean, it seems crazy, but also possible. Nothing about this process the last few months made me want to quit. Whether or not I actually make it all the way I feel like I’m having fun right now, like I’m building up a sustainable running practice, and I’m learning a lot about what motivates me to keep going, and of which is worth it.

And I can still run one whole mile without stopping. And that still does feel pretty cool!

That said, I’ve learned a bit about how goal motivated I am. Races‚Äîas much as I anguish over them‚Äîbring structure and focus to all the runs that come before them. So I’m going to keep doing them, and I’m planning on doing two more half-marathons in 2023. I want to re-run the Fall Classic in November, because I want to have at least one year-over-year apples-to-apples comparison, just to see what there is to see. Before that I want to try for a late spring race, I think, because I’d like to run at least one of these races in (hopefully) nice weather. I’ve earned that!

I’m also ready to care about pace a little more. Admittedly, I ran the November race slow enough that it would be tough not to beat that time next time out, after another round of training, but also I just know I can go faster than that, and I want to specifically try for that. I never expect to be competitive at these things, nor am I interested in trying hard enough to be. But I also know it’s fun to surprise yourself, and I can get behind trying hard enough for that. So I’m setting out with the loose goal this spring of beating my first time, and then going for something reasonably ambitious in the fall.

To that end, in the short term, I want to run more during the next training cycle. Not necessarily harder, but more. I know I trained at about the barest possible minimal level for the fall race. Next time out I want to go from three days a week to four. I think I’m going to repeat the same basic 12-week training calendar as the last time out, which I liked the general feel of, with the addition of the fourth day, which would be a shorter, light/easy day. I have no plans to target five days as I want to keep a day or two free for an elliptical session or finding a strength training or yoga habit I like.

While I said I don’t necessarily want to run harder, I do generally want to bring my paces up across the board. Sometimes these last few months I felt fine, sometimes I felt like I had more to give but was holding back. I’m still not quite sure what easy should actually feel like but I think just in general the more I run the more efficient I get and if I can maintain my consistency through into the new year I’ll naturally feel a little more okay going a little more fast a little more often. Maybe more importantly though, for confidence purposes, I want to push my race pace experiments more aggressively. I want to pick an ambitious target early and stick with it the whole way through. I really wasn’t sure what felt right this last time through, and now I think I want to use those runs to push myself to give a little more. Still, even if it’s nothing like what I run on race day, having those faster days in the training cycle feels fun.

I’m also hoping to do some shorter races that I can really try for my best-possible paces. I’m thinking about re-doing the 10k I ran last spring, which left me feeling like I had something unresolved there that I’d like to make good on. I’m also curious to see if I can beat my summer 5k race’s time from last year, too. Which actually feels like it could be the most ambitious goal of the year! If I find some 10k races that fit in with the half marathon plans, I might try to slide those in, too, for practice purposes, but I’m not sure that’s going to work out or not.

So that’s the year in a nutshell, as I picture it right now: a half, some shorter stuff, and then a give-it-my-all half by the year’s end. Working on confidence, pace, and strength. And then all going well, launching into full marathon training come January 2024.

items.title: Week twelve running report ... race week! üèÉ
items.content_html:
Monday afternoon, about 24 hours after I crossed the finish line, is when I finally started to believe that I’d just run my first half marathon. I felt pretty spaced out before that, like I’d been walking through a post-race cloud, and it was only when I started to come out of it that I felt like I could not just know I did it as a fact but feel that I did it as a truth. If that makes sense. Like I could feel the nervous energy start to dissipate into a sense of accomplishment. It made for a nice post-race high.

That said: oh my lord, I have never before felt cold like I did right after that race.

To back up a bit: the week before the race I continued my taper. It got a little weird! I’d planned on Tuesday/Thursday runs like usual with super-easy Monday/Friday elliptical sessions, all basically just to keep loose while resting up. Monday went fine, then Tuesday fell apart for various reasons, including truly miserable weather, and I wound up cancelling. So then I went back out for a handful of miles Wednesday night, a few at “race pace,” then had to turn around and get up early on Friday to get one more run in before work and the weekend. It all worked out fine, and my fears of over-sleeping Friday came to nothing, but the whole stutter-step of a final week’s schedule was slightly nerve-wracking.

I felt good Friday, and slept like a baby that night, which was nice, because I knew I’d probably not sleep like a baby the night before the race. (Spoiler alert: I did not sleep good Saturday night.) Saturday felt like one of the longest days of my life. I’m learning just how susceptible I am to pre-race nerves. I know it’s healthy to a degree, the body’s way of getting amped up for the coming event. But I also think I was tipping a bit past “excitement” and more into “bro, you must chill” territory. I did not enjoy myself much that day. Again, everything worked out! But I know I want to work out a better day-before strategy for the future.

Leading up to race day I was watching the weather forecast. Specifically, I was watching the forecasted temperature drop like a rock. Signing up for a late November race in northeast Ohio, I have some idea what I’m getting myself into. But! Yikes! Based on my experience at the 5k at the same event last year, I was happily anticipating low-40s, gray clouds, maybe some fog. You know…perfect running weather. I was not prepared for the low 20s. With a wind chill that took it down to single-digit territory.

“How cold was it,” you ask? Could enough that I’d never adequately had the chance to test race day gear‚ÄîI’d run in three layers of clothing earlier that week, but decided at the last minute to throw on a fourth vest layer on top on my running fleece layer. Cold enough that every time I thought I was warmed up enough during the run that I could unzip those top two layers to vent, I was zipping back up within minutes. Cold enough that the water they were giving out on the course was actually freezing‚Äîat least, there were definitely ice chips in mine. Cold enough that a friend of mine said her water pack vest froze up on her, so she couldn’t use it during the race. Like, this was not fun running cold. This was real cold. Did I need to score those extra bad-ass points my first time out? No. Did I, though? I guess so!

The good news is the snow that hit near my house up by the lake was a non-issue to the south, and we got some beautiful (if heatless) sun for the entirety of the race, too. Good for keeping spirits up, at least. And yet, still, it was cold cold.

As for how I did: I did it. If you’ve been following along you know my one goal going into the run was to run the whole way and…I did that. I ran the whole way. I took full advantage of my “I don’t care about pace this time out” mindset. My pace was way at the slowest end of my anticipated range, but I still came in just ahead of my “Something probably went wrong” time. I’ll take it! I definitely went very conservative on pacing, as thoughts of burning out early were strong. And of course the weather this fall was way too kind, affording no appropriate lead-in down to race-day temperatures.

All that said, there really were some nice stretches in the middle where the miles did kind of melt into each other. Five through eight, maybe? Things did get uglier as I went on, though. While I knew for a fact I could do it, I still felt like I had to dig in a bit to convince myself that I was going to do it. That it was going to be way more fun to be able to tell everyone afterward that I did in fact make it. That working for the hard thing, and then achieving it, was exactly the kind of example I wanted to set for my two kids. That if I stopped running, it was going to be a real cold walk back to the finish line…

The course was nice‚Äîan out-and-back double-loop along the Cleveland Metroparks parkway drive. Quiet; I did in fact run without music, to prove to myself I could, and without getting into future plans yet, I’m not sure I’m going to feel the need to do that again! Not much in the way of spectators, of course, because of the weather and because of where the course was run. It was fun to see all the fast people running back the other way several times over from my back-of-the-pack vantage point. Huge props to all the volunteers along the course. Every kind word was incredible.

Crossing the finish line, which I finally actually really believed I was going to do once I finally caught sight of it, wasn’t exactly anti-climactic, but it also wasn’t really accompanied by an orchestral swell, either‚Äîthat feeling, as I said above, really didn’t come until 24 hours later. Crossing the finish line mostly meant oh my god wow I can stop running now. Which felt really nice for a while. Until the cold settled in. Which I knew to anticipate, but, like, I couldn’t really anticipate what standing in freezing temperatures in four sweaty layers was actually going to feel like. Suffice it to say I did not finish my post-race beer‚Äîthough no cold was going to stop me from having at least a few victory chugs‚Äîbefore I went home, showered with all the hot water in the house, and then collapsed under multiple blankets for a few hours, until my body finally felt almost warm again.

And thus concludes my first half-marathon training cycle, which was as much about the journey as the destination. It’s been a week and I’m feeling surprisingly good. I was concerned about post-race blues, but knock on wood, so far my spirits have stayed up‚Äîlanding the race right before a busy holiday week probably helped with that. And knowing even before going into the race that it was always going to be part of a bigger picture, with some next steps already tentatively laid out, certainly hasn’t hurt. For now, though, I’ve been out for a couple short, light recovery runs, and I’m feeling okay, and I think it’s going to be nice to just run for fun with no training expectations for a little while, which I haven’t actually done since…April, I think? What a wild year it has been…

Cold enough that the water they were giving out on the course was actually freezing‚Äîat least, there were definitely ice chips in mine. Cold enough that a friend of mine said her water pack vest froze up on her, so she couldn't use it during the race. Like, this was not fun running cold. This was *real* cold. Did I need to score those extra bad-ass points my first time out? No. Did I, though? I guess so!

The good news is the snow that hit near my house up by the lake was a non-issue to the south, and we got some beautiful (if heatless) sun for the entirety of the race, too. Good for keeping spirits up, at least. And yet, still, it was *cold* cold. 

As for how I did: I did it. If you've been following along you know my one goal going into the run was to run the whole way and...I did that. I ran the whole way. I took full advantage of my "I don't care about pace this time out" mindset. My pace was way at the slowest end of my anticipated range, but I still came in just ahead of my "Something probably went wrong" time. I'll take it! I definitely went very conservative on pacing, as thoughts of burning out early were strong. And of course the weather this fall was way too kind, affording no appropriate lead-in down to race-day temperatures.

All that said, there really were some nice stretches in the middle where the miles did kind of melt into each other. Five through eight, maybe? Things did get uglier as I went on, though. While I knew for a fact I could do it, I still felt like I had to dig in a bit to convince myself that I was *going* to do it. That it was going to be *way* more fun to be able to tell everyone afterward that I did in fact make it. That working for the hard thing, and then achieving it, was exactly the kind of example I wanted to set for my two kids. That if I stopped running, it was going to be a real cold walk back to the finish line...

The course was nice‚Äîan out-and-back double-loop along the Cleveland Metroparks parkway drive. Quiet; I did in fact run without music, to prove to myself I could, and without getting into future plans yet, I'm not sure I'm going to feel the need to do that again! Not much in the way of spectators, of course, because of the weather and because of where the course was run. It was fun to see all the fast people running back the other way several times over from my back-of-the-pack vantage point. Huge props to all the volunteers along the course. Every kind word was incredible.

Crossing the finish line, which I finally actually really believed I was going to do once I finally caught sight of it, wasn't exactly anti-climactic, but it also wasn't really accompanied by an orchestral swell, either‚Äîthat feeling, as I said above, really didn't come until 24 hours later. Crossing the finish line mostly meant *oh my god wow I can stop running now*. Which felt really nice for a while. Until the cold settled in. Which I knew to anticipate, but, like, I couldn't *really* anticipate what standing in freezing temperatures in four sweaty layers was actually going to feel like. Suffice it to say I did not finish my post-race beer‚Äîthough no cold was going to stop me from having at least a few victory chugs‚Äîbefore I went home, showered with all the hot water in the house, and then collapsed under multiple blankets for a few hours, until my body finally felt *almost* warm again.

And thus concludes my first half-marathon training cycle, which was as much about the journey as the destination. It's been a week and I'm feeling surprisingly good. I was concerned about post-race blues, but knock on wood, so far my spirits have stayed up‚Äîlanding the race right before a busy holiday week probably helped with that. And knowing even before going into the race that it was always going to be part of a bigger picture, with some next steps already tentatively laid out, certainly hasn't hurt. For now, though, I've been out for a couple short, light recovery runs, and I'm feeling okay, and I think it's going to be nice to just run for fun with no training expectations for a little while, which I haven't actually done since...April, I think? What a wild year it has been...

items.title: Week eleven running report üèÉ
items.content_html:
Taper week! Ran four easy miles on Tuesday, four miles on Thursday with two of those at race pace, and five miles on Saturday, my shortest long run since week two. If I was bemoaning the lack of seasonably appropriate training weather the last few weeks, well, Saturday’s run threw a big bucket of cold drizzly slushy nonsense right in my face. Felt good to have at least one proper day for testing out possible race day clothing, I suppose?

I knew going into the week I was ready for this taper time, and while I don’t have anything extremely specific to point at to confirm this, I can say I do feel like I’m…actively recharging. Like I can now not just know but also feel the fact that I’ve made real gains the last few months. If running week ten’s total of 22.5 miles was a stretch and a challenge, one I felt proud to meet, running this week’s total of 13 miles left me feeling like my body knew it had more to give. And I’m both nervous and excited about tapping into that feeling this coming weekend. (How unfair is it, by the way, that it’s when you have the most nervous energy, that you least get to do the thing that helps you vent that energy?)

All of which…brings us to this coming Sunday. My goal for the race remains as clear as it has been since the start‚Äîget to the finish line without walking breaks. I know for a fact now that I can make it twelve miles‚Äîwhen I’m pretty well under-rested, at that!‚Äîand I think I can reasonably trust that a mix of adrenaline and pure stubbornness will get me past the last 1.1 miles. I’m feeling generally confident about this.

The strategy to get to that point feels like it’s all about how I start the race. That’s where I’ve got some mental baggage I need to shed: the first time I did a 5k and the one time I’ve done a 10k, adrenaline and nerves pushed me out too hot, which killed me later in the run. I started training for this race assuming there’s a good chance I’d make similar mistakes…but now that I’ve gotten to this point, I really, obviously don’t want to! So I’m hoping to learn from my past and to manage my nerves as I wait for the start, and to keep things real conservative and chill for as long as feels right. I’ve been trying to listen to my body during my long runs, and I’ve been trying to figure out when and how to ease up before reaching that red-line zone, without needing to come to a stop. If I feel good toward the middle of the race I know I can loosen up a bit more, and I hope there’s a point toward the end when I can stop holding back and just go, because that sounds like it would be really, really fun…but to get to those points I need to avoid frying myself too early.

Part of all this is reminding myself that I don’t have a time goal this time out. I have a general idea where I “should” fall but I’m choosing not to make that my concern this time. In large part because, well…like, this whole process has been an education and a trial, and as part of that, pace has been generally mysterious to me, anyways. Like: Saturday’s miles felt easy, but turned out to be a bit on the quick side of my recent range, but not quite at the race pace I’ve been practicing at (without any real intent of actually meeting on race day!). It felt really good; does it feel like the kind of easy-fast I can keep for a half-marathon? No idea! At this point I can happily admit I’ve never had a good sense these last few months of what my pace zones should feel like. Whatever does happen Sunday I know I’ve made obvious gains that I think I can have fun playing around with going forward.

Which, yes, I have a lot of thoughts already about the going forward part. Which I am trying hard to keep on a shelf for the moment. Because for now I’ve got a couple more taper runs to get through and then it’s time to go do the thing. (Okay, maybe I can go ahead and visualize going forward, a little bit…specifically, going forward from the finish line to the beer garden?…)

items.title: Week ten running report üèÉ
items.content_html:
AKA‚Ä¶peak week!

Spoiler alert: I made it!

Tuesday was 4.5 miles, easy, down from last week‚Äôs five. I‚Äôve been letting these ‚Äúeasy‚Äù runs get away from me, so, knowing this week‚Äòs other two runs were going to be intense in their own ways, I consciously kept this one light. The kind of light that feels comical. Like, am I even running? I think I was successful. Kept my pace slow-for-me and heart rate down, and felt pretty good at the end. It‚Äôs a bit late in the game to reconnect with this kind of run for this training cycle, though it will come in handy during tapering, for sure. And it will be worth focusing on after the race, too.

Thursday‚Äôs race pace run added a full mile, taking me up to four miles of pace (plus warm up and cool down miles). I kept that pace right around where I‚Äôd kept it the week before, with relatively few ‚ÄúSlow down, dummy!‚Äù alerts from my watch, all the way through the fourth mile. It felt really good and also oh gee did I feel it afterward, all the way through Friday. (It wasn‚Äôt exactly concerning so much as I felt generally beat up. Like I‚Äôve been training for ten solid weeks to run my first half-marathon, or something. I imagine it would be weirder if I were still feeling extra fresh right now, right?) These pace runs have remained fun, though they still feel a bit aspirational. I‚Äôm not planning to actively seek that pace during this race, but maybe I‚Äôve laid some good groundwork for future races.

Then came Saturday‚Äôs twelve miler, a big jump from last week‚Äôs ten. My dream of the perfectly restorative night‚Äôs sleep didn‚Äôt pan out, and while I felt somewhat better this morning, I know I wasn‚Äôt back to one hundred percent, either. So I‚Äôm not surprised my average pace was slower than my last few long runs‚Ä¶but I am actually pleasantly surprised that I made it all twelve miles. (Those miles past ten are real big Life Choices, aren‚Äôt they?)

I set my watch to alert me every three miles, which felt right; it wasn‚Äôt a twelve mile run, it wasn‚Äôt a run two miles longer than my last long run, it was just four three mile runs, back to back! For that first three miles I felt tight, like the whole thing was going to be too much work, and I was a little certain I was going to bag the whole thing by the halfway point. But‚Ä¶once I got into sections two and three, I loosened up, and it really didn‚Äôt feel so bad for a while. Until I got into the last segment, when my body was really starting to complain. Still, even then, that last bit of adrenaline pumped in, and I pulled off a nice final kick. Not my fastest stretch ever, but boy oh boy did realizing I was still doing the thing feel amazing.

Which, again, just doing the thing is about all I‚Äôm looking for this time out, come race day. Race day, which is now two weeks away, on the other side of some sweet, sweet, sweet tapering. Oh, yes, I am looking forward to tapering. The rest is going to be nice. As will be not waking up approximately a million hours before dawn next Saturday!

items.title: Week nine running report üèÉ
items.content_html:
When I started writing up these weekly summaries, I wanted to document the downs as much as the ups, and based on my experience training for the 5k in July, I honestly thought there‚Äôd be more dramatic downs. Missed runs, weird injuries, crummy weeks. Knock on wood, there hasn‚Äôt been much of any of that. There‚Äôs minor things, weird things I‚Äôm maybe not getting into much, in the interest of keeping these updates somewhat brief, or maybe because I‚Äôm doing a bad job of writing down as much as I actually should. But‚Ä¶while I would never describe this process as easy, I‚Äòm also really surprised‚Äîand, of course, pleased‚Äîat how generally smooth things have been going.

Case in point: after the slightly weird, mildly narratively interesting week that was week eight, week nine felt‚Ä¶pretty fine! Essentially uneventful! Except of course not exactly uneventful because I ran 20 miles this week for the second time ever, which is certainly an event. But it also kind of just happened, which is nice.

Five of those miles came from my easy run on Tuesday, which became an unintentional race pace kind of run for a bit, because I kind of just felt good and the weather kind of just felt perfect and I kind of just went faster than I meant to. It did not suck.

Another five miles came from my actual race pace run on Thursday. In an effort to avoid the ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to go extra sort of fast for the last stretch‚Äù thing I‚Äôve been doing the last few weeks, I set my watch to just notify me when the three race pace miles were done, rather than notifying me at each mile. That helped, I think. I mean, it made the race pace segment feel very long, but it stayed pretty steady, which felt nice.

And then of course ten miles came on Saturday morning, which had me out the door before sunrise. I kept the route generally more flat than the previous time I went out for ten miles. It felt long, but it also felt pretty good; certainly better than the week previous. I definitely felt like I needed to push myself to finish, a bit, near the end‚Äîten miles really is so many miles! I think it showed up in my pace graph; my first three miles were on my slower side, but then my last three miles were pretty fast, the last two actually edging into my hypothetical race pace range. All in, where my last three long runs all hit the exact same average pace, this one landed the average at exactly two seconds faster. I‚Äôll take it!

I know, intuitively, that running can be as much a mental game as a physical one. That said, it has long been hard to imagine ever reaching the point where a run could get long enough to become kind of boring. While I‚Äôm not exactly there yet, I feel like I can see that territory around me, now, on some of these runs. I‚Äôm starting to consciously play with that a bit.

So like, for this long run, instead of having my watch buzz me after every mile, I had it buzz me after every 2.5 miles, to see what it feels like when I thought of the run less as being a collection of ten miles and more as four longer segments. I‚Äôm not sure how much of a difference it made, until near the end, when that last segment started, and it felt like, somewhat irrationally, it was going to be so much longer than all the others.

More dramatically, I also took this long run without music. Though I run with music all the time‚Äîa subject worth its own post‚ÄîI‚Äôll leave the headphones behind on race day. It‚Äôs not that I‚Äôm worried anyone‚Äôs going to think I‚Äôm tempo matching or anything‚ÄîI‚Äôm clearly too slow for that to even matter! It‚Äôs more out of, in part, wanting to keep my situational awareness levels up, as I never run with others around me, and also, in part, because letting in spectator noise, picking up that energy, feels really cool; in the shorter races I‚Äôve done, it‚Äôs a huge part of what‚Äôs made the actual race feel like a real thing. Still, thirteen (point one!) miles is a long time to run without one of my primary crutches, and I wanted to take at least one test run ahead of time without music to make sure I actually could do it. Confirmed: I can actually do it! At least, I can for ten miles. I‚Äôll have to trust race day adrenaline will keep me going for the last three, though, because I‚Äôm definitely soundtracking next week‚Äôs twelve miler. It‚Äôs just way more fun that way.

Three more weeks to go.

items.title: Week eight running report üèÉ
items.content_html:
I was in a weird headspace this week. Nothing calamitous, just enough to feel slightly off. Despite two of my three runs going longer, it was still technically a lighter week in terms of total mileage, so I guess if there was a week to feel a bit off, this was the one.

My Tuesday evening easy run went up to 4.5 miles. After several failed attempts to run early to avoid rain, I wound up running at my usual time‚Ä¶in the rain. It was fine. Fairly light. Cold, though. I’m glad I invested earlier this year in a good rain jacket for running.

Thursday took me out for five miles, three playing with race pace. I kept a pleasant pace for the first two then pushed it for number three, going fast-for-me and definitely outside my distance-run comfort zone. Fun to go past the point of sustainability, though I really do want to convince myself to keep it in check the next couple weeks. I think there’s a sweet spot in there somewhere. Not sure I’m going to feel comfortable trying for it this coming race, because really still all I want to do is get to that finish line in one piece. But, again, fun to play. And maybe lay groundwork for mnore ambitious (yet still hypothetical) future attempts.

Saturday’s long run was eight miles. Ignoring the fact that I only actually just ran eight for the first time ever three weeks earlier, I took a slightly-too-nonchalant attitude toward this run, because it was technically less than the previous week’s ten miles. Eight, after doing ten? Ought to be a breeze, right? So after three morning long runs I went back to my usual afternoon slot, after spending the morning out with my family, putting in at least a mile of photography-and-kids-chasing time around Metroparks trails. Then I had a heavy lunch, much heavier than the lighter “let’s see what might actually work on race day” breakfasts I’ve been trying out. Oh, and it was like 30 degrees warmer outside than either of my weekday runs from this week.

Long story short, this run felt ugly. But! My average pace exactly matched that from the previous two long runs. Three long runs in a row with the exact same average pace is weird, right?

So, glad I got it done, grateful for the educational experience, but I’m also happy to put this week behind me. Feels like one to shake off, like a good time to take a deep breath and recenter. The next two weeks are doozies for me, at 20 and 22.5 miles, respectively. I’ll definitely be trying to get back out in the morning for those long runs.

Four weeks until race day! Four weeks until race day? Four weeks until race day…

items.title: Week seven running report üèÉ
items.content_html:
I live in Lakewood, a fairly dense city directly to the west of Cleveland. I work forty minutes outside Cleveland, in Oberlin, which is surrounded by farmland. I used to run down there a lot back in 2019, when I first started running, doing my couch-to-5k program. Then, something happened, in 2020, and I didn’t run down there much? I’m not sure, the timeline gets a little blurry…

In any case, I’ve been craving some fresh scenery, so I finally remembered to pack my stuff and take it with me this past week, so I could do my weekday runs out of the office. It felt weird! I guess I have a lot of place-memory/sense-memory of struggle-running down there, of thinking three miles was so flipping far, and coming into this week, I had a weird amount of pointless nervous energy built up, like I was going to immediately fall on my face as soon as I started, or something.

For Tuesday I did a specific four mile loop that I’d eyed up as a big crazy stretch goal route back in 2019. It felt so ambitious, back then. Little did I imagine when I’d finally run it it would be totally chill weekday training. Training for a run more than three times longer than that one. No big deal. (Basically. I actually went maybe one notch harder than I probably should have. I blame coming off the extra rest day as my schedule slid back to normal; I felt a little coiled up, going into it. Went okay, in any event, so it’s cool.)

With most of my running happening in urban areas, it was fun to add some corn into the mix.

Thursday had me going 4.5 miles, with 2.5 at “race” pace. I successfully kept the race pace slower by about 30 seconds for the first two miles (before I kicked it up a bit for the last half mile, because why not) from where I’d been the week before, when I’d felt I’d been going a bit too hard for something sustainable. This felt really good. This felt like the fun kind of tempo run/threshold run/“this feels like a good workout” run I remember from 5k training in the summer. Faster, for me, without feeling like I was punishing myself. It’s a really fun run to include in the weekly mix. (I kind of miss interval running, but I definitely missed these tempo runs.) Still probably not a realistic pace for the whole race, but maybe something I could reach for on the back third, when the final puddle of adrenaline has nowhere else to go?

And then there’s this week’s huge milestone: my first 10 mile run.

I tried to spin this into a coherent narrative, but really I just have lots of random thoughts and observations:

  • I made it! Wow!
  • It’s not to say that my first nine and my first eight mile runs weren‚Äôt huge milestones, but something about crossing over into double-digit territory feels significant.
  • Wildly…ten felt easier than nine. There’s a lot of reasons why that could be. I‚Äôve been adding a mile to the long run each week for seven straight weeks now, and maybe finally my body was just like, ‚ÄúOh, okay, yup, this is what we do, now." Maybe there was a little extra adrenaline kick from going to ten. Maybe it was the route, or the time of day, or the breeze hit just right, or something I ate. Maybe I actually stayed in bed and dreamed the whole run? I don’t know. I am not complaining.
  • I am decidedly not a morning person. I do most of my running at night or in the afternoon, partially because of life scheduling and partially because I am decidedly not a morning person. Because of scheduling I had to get up for this one at 5:30 AM, though, like some kind of “real” runner. I was nervous about that, both about actually responding to the alarm that early and then about my body actually doing the thing, which I’ve historically had some issues with. But clearly everything worked out.
  • I ran ten miles. Ten miles.
  • The ascending pace graph wasn’t as picture-perfect as the nine miler from the week before, but it was still very, very pretty, and when you average it out to 2.5 mile splits, it looked even nicer. I like this because it’s not something I’m explicitly trying for, and it’s nice to feel like my body is kind of doing something “right” without me having to force it. It felt natural, I guess.
  • I explored a lot of options for the route, then just wound up…going. Which was fun. My city’s about 6-ish square miles of city blocks, and I live pretty close to smack dab in the center of it, and it turns out it’s pretty easy to wind up and down and around to get the miles in without too much planning, so long as you’re vaguely aware of how far from home you’ve gotten. (I like trying to know about where I’m going to end a run; visualizing a finish line keeps me going.)
  • I wound up doing a lot of north-south back-and-forth, which is fun, because when you go south, away from the lake, you can get a bit of an upward climb, and then when you head back north, you can get a bit of a descent. Not much! Not even close to much! Ohio’s pretty flat around where I’m at. But literally any climbing is more climbing than no climbing. Just having that little bit of variance in the route helps keep things interesting. All told I think it added up to about three times more “climbing” than the half-marathon route will entail. I probably actually need to consciously make sure my long runs are more flat just to make sure that’s not a big factor come race day.
  • Did I mention the part where I ran for ten miles?
  • Up to this run I’ve generally felt okay about this project‚Äîlike the half-marathon goal is possible, but still kind of a huge abstraction, something I’m working toward, but who knows if I’ll actually make it. With this run I finally felt like, yeah, okay: I’ve got this. Not that I’m going to get cocky or anything, there’s still a lot miles between me and the finish line, but I actually definitely mostly sort of kind of feel like I’m probably certainly maybe going to make it. Potentially! Which is a cool feeling.

This coming week brings a relative breather‚Äîmy two weekday runs both go up by half a mile but my weekend run drops back to eight, the first time my weekend run goes shorter since I began the training plan. (“Shorter” in this case meaning “will qualify as one of my four longest runs ever to date.") So I lose a mile this week but then the following two weeks pack on multiple extra miles ahead of the taper week. Those two weeks will probably put my whole good-vibes feeling to the test, I suspect.

This coming week brings a relative breather‚Äîmy two weekday runs both go up by half a mile but my weekend run drops back to eight, the first time my weekend run goes shorter since I began the training plan. ("Shorter" in this case meaning "will qualify as one of my four longest runs ever to date.") So I lose a mile this week but then the following two weeks pack on multiple extra miles ahead of the taper week. Those two weeks will probably put my whole good-vibes feeling to the test, I suspect.

items.title: Week six running report üèÉ
items.content_html:
Okay! Week six! The build continues, with a nine mile run following last week‚Äôs eight miler. And it went swimmingly: without really trying, I managed to create the most beautiful pace graph ever, with every mile either at or a bit above the pace of the previous mile, right on through to the end. Even past the point around the start of mile seven when I started having mild doubts about whether or not I was even going to make it to the end. Cardiovascularly I was feeling pretty good, and my energy level was okay, though I was definitely feeling it‚Äîthe basic endurance required to just keep going for that long is truly something else‚Ä¶but oh gosh did my legs feel like I was trying to run nine miles for the first time a week after running eight miles for the first time. Not horrible, but not exactly strain-free, either! It‚Äôs possible there was some internal motivational screaming happening during mile eight. It‚Äôs possible there was some audible motivational screaming happening in mile nine. Possibly! Maybe! It‚Äôs fine. I‚Äôm fine and definitely not crazy or weird.

We‚Äôre at the point here near Cleveland where the temperature is starting to drop, which makes me start thinking really hard about hey wait how the heck do I dress for these conditions again? I‚Äôve been through enough of these cycles now that I‚Äôm going into this fall season knowing well that I just run hot, in general, doubly so when I‚Äôm actually running, and that whatever other people might be wearing, I‚Äôm going to be better off wearing less than what my rational mind tells me to wear. For today‚Äôs low-fifties-and-overcast run, that meant skipping the extra layers I was starting to think I should start thinking about piling on. Though I did upgrade from a thin running shirt to a merino running shirt! Short sleeves, though! Felt good, and once I warmed up a bit, it took stronger gusts to remind me that, hey, it was actually kind of chilly out there. But yeah, it‚Äôs probably time to think about pulling out the extra stuff.

The easy four miler on Monday was‚Ä¶an easy four miles. I ran a weird route because I‚Äôve got this side thing going where I‚Äôm trying to run so that my heat map on Strava eventually indicates that I‚Äôve run every single street in Lakewood. Picked up a couple streets that I‚Äôd somehow skipped over to date. It‚Äôs a silly project but a fun way to force me to mix up my routes a bit, now and then. (There‚Äôs going to be some really weird runs in my future dedicated to logging time on weird little tiny side streets.)

My pace race run on Wednesday, I was up to two miles of race pace running, for which I‚Äôd slid my target pace another thirty seconds faster from the week previous, and I landed both miles pretty close to the fastest end of that minute. And‚Ä¶yeah, I think it‚Äôs time to try to figure out how to consciously slide my pace back into the slower half of that minute. I think what I‚Äôm looking for is a pace where it feels like I‚Äôm running fast but not hard; the race pace portion of Wednesday‚Äôs run was fast, for me, but probably a bit too hard, for a sustainable long-distance effort. Or at least, I don‚Äôt feel compelled to try to maintain that pace for that long, not yet, not at this stage. I‚Äôm just not quite sure that I know how to fine-tune my pace to such a degree, yet, though I guess actually consciously trying to will be a good start!

Which all brings me to the exact halfway point of this half-marathon training plan. At least in terms of weeks‚Äîthere‚Äôs a lot of miles to cover yet! Right now, today, eight hours after I finished my long run, I‚Äôm feeling pretty good about all this. I feel like, so long as I can keep my motivation up, I‚Äôm still on track to make it to that half-marathon finish line in something resembling one piece. Knock on wood, fingers crossed, all that good stuff‚Ä¶.

items.content_html:
Throwing a couple bookmarklet code samples up here for reference.

These stemmed from this conversation thread which finally got me thinking about a couple super simple bookmarklets I could add for my own convenience. Add these as bookmarks to the browser toolbar, and click them as needed to filter out posts. They’re not feature-rich, they’re one-way only (i.e., to un-hide posts, you need to refresh the page!), and they’re only tested (barely) in Firefox, so anyone else’s mileage may vary.

Here’s a JS bookmarklet for hiding MB posts from the https://micro.blog timeline based on length. The “25” in the middle is a character count‚Äîthat can be manually fine-tuned by changing the number, to hide various lengths of posts. Because sometimes there’s lots of tiny short posts that fill up the timeline, and this is a way to quickly hide them, for convenience.

javascript: (() => { document.querySelectorAll('.post').forEach(post => {   const text = post.querySelector('.post_text');   if (text.innerText.length < 25 ) {     post.style.display = "none";   } })})()

Here’s a JS bookmarklet for hiding MB @ mention posts from the the https://micro.blog timeline. It’s just looking for an ‘@’ at the start of the post, and if it finds it, it hides the post. Because sometimes you want to see mentions because they lead to interesting conversations you wouldn’t have otherwise discovered, and other times you just want to filter them out so you can see top-level posts by themselves.

javascript: (() => { document.querySelectorAll('.post').forEach(post => {      const text = post.querySelector('.post_text');   if (text.innerText[0] === '@' ) {     post.style.display = "none";   } })})()

These stemmed from [this conversation thread](https://micro.blog/amit/13460628) which finally got me thinking about a couple super simple bookmarklets I could add for my own convenience. Add these as bookmarks to the browser toolbar, and click them as needed to filter out posts. They're not feature-rich, they're one-way only (i.e., to un-hide posts, you need to refresh the page!), and they're only tested (barely) in Firefox, so anyone else's mileage may vary.

Here's a JS bookmarklet for hiding MB posts from the https://micro.blog timeline based on length. The "25" in the middle is a character count‚Äîthat can be manually fine-tuned by changing the number, to hide various lengths of posts. Because sometimes there's lots of tiny short posts that fill up the timeline, and this is a way to quickly hide them, for convenience.

```
javascript: (() => { document.querySelectorAll('.post').forEach(post => {   const text = post.querySelector('.post_text');   if (text.innerText.length < 25 ) {     post.style.display = "none";   } })})()
```

Here's a JS bookmarklet for hiding MB @ mention posts from the the https://micro.blog timeline. It's just looking for an '@' at the start of the post, and if it finds it, it hides the post. Because sometimes you want to see mentions because they lead to interesting conversations you wouldn't have otherwise discovered, and other times you just want to filter them out so you can see top-level posts by themselves.

```
javascript: (() => { document.querySelectorAll('.post').forEach(post => {      const text = post.querySelector('.post_text');   if (text.innerText[0] === '@' ) {     post.style.display = "none";   } })})()
```

items.title: Week five running report üèÉ
items.content_html:
For my second race pace run, this Wednesday, I‚Äôd set my target pace range minute 30 seconds faster than the prior week‚Äôs target, based on the earlier week’s pace. Then I did the first mile 15 seconds faster than that. And the following half mile at a 45 seconds faster pace. Which felt amazing but also whaaaaat? I don’t know. Either my body is telling me something my mind doesn’t know what to do with, or my mind hasn’t clearly communicated the real plan to my body yet. So I’m kind of torn. I could try to let it rip like this for as long as I can, because after all, I clearly have no idea what my pace ranges actually are or should be, and seeing how far I can push these paces is definitely educational. On the flip side I could try to reign it back in, and try harder to target something closer to my easy run paces‚Äîfaster, still, but not that much faster, so I gain a better sense of what an ambitious, but also realistic, pace feels like. I think I’m going to just roll with it for another week before trying to course-correct just yet. If nothing else, it does feel really good to have this kind of fast-for-me run in the mix.

Did my long run on Friday. 8 miles. My new longest run ever! Felt good! Felt long! Can’t believe I’m going to turn back around and go 9 miles this coming week! For as weirdly anxious as I was going into the run, my pace felt good, generally in the lower half of my original minute target range; I slowed down a bit around mile six, which, coincidentally, I’m sure, was the one part of the run with something resembling actual climb. Then I finished strong. My last mile was my fastest. Whatever is happening on race pace days, I’d be one hundred percent happy with running the half marathon the way I’m running these weekend long runs, if it means successfully running the whole way without bonking out or redlining mid-race.

Worth noting, I’m generally trying to be conscious of how I feel between the runs, as one way of gauging how I’m doing, and so far everything has felt, as best as I can tell, within reasonable bounds of expectation. I only felt a little rickety, this Saturday, is what I’m saying. As a relatively old man doing his first half-marathon training I’ll take “a little rickety” any day!

Monday’s easy four miler? It rained. Hard. I was drenched within a minute of walking out the door. It was fine enough once I got going, and then it actually mostly stopped raining for the middle portion of the run. Then the rain returned with a vengeance for the final mile. it’s been a week and I may actually still be soaked through from that run. I may never be dry again. Honestly the novelty of running in weather that probably made me look like an absolute crazy person was kind of worth it, it was certainly an interesting thing to do, but here’s to hoping I don’t have to make a habit out of it.

The other interesting thing about this week was that I’d had to pull all these runs forward a day due to weekend scheduling conflicts. I can clearly say I did fine‚ÄîI did it!‚Äîbut also I felt sort of like could feel that missing extra full rest day, a bit. Not by much, and it felt good to know I could push through that, but there was maybe an extra notch of ugh on the old fatigue meter this week. I wasn’t upset when I hit the weekend and had something resembling a full downtime day on Sunday.

I also haven’t mentioned cross-training efforts here yet, I think, mostly because they’re not interesting, but I’m generally keeping up with them, which is nice; if nothing else, increasing my activity level across the week is a plus. It’s typically been either an elliptical session or a bike ride, neither too strenous, just enough to loosen up. Mostly it’s been the elliptical, as the weather has started turning. (As much as biking is my first love, it sure is easier to run in the cold than to bike.) I’ve hit every middle-of-the-week session so far, with weekends being a bit spottier, based on general life happenings. So, like, this past Saturday I couldn’t do anything formal, but after walking around Michigan parks for over 11,000 steps with my family, I think I can say: I’m good!

Final bonus fun fact: I listened to the new Fujiya & Miyagi album for the first time during my long run. They’re great. The album is great. Hearing David Best sing the line “We’re closer to the end than we are the beginning” as I was literally crossing the four-mile midpoint of the run? Truly cosmic.

items.title: Week four running report üèÉ
items.content_html:
I‚Äôd flagged this week as the start of my build phase, but now I think it was maybe my last ‚Äúgimme‚Äù week‚Äîthere wasn’t anything in the plan I haven’t done before and it was mostly a question of doing it now as proof that I could be ready in time for what comes next. So I guess I’ll call it a transition week?

My long run on Saturday was seven miles. I’ve done seven before, a handful of times, and I felt comfortable taking it on this time, even keeping an average pace a notch faster than last week‚Äôs six miler. The weather didn’t hurt‚Äîpicture-perfect for running, overcast, low 60s, some breeze. In the past every time I’ve hit this kind of distance I think I’ve started to realize just how much the long run game is a mental one as it is a physical one. Running at a comfortable pace means feeling like I could, theoretically, physically do it forever; convincing myself, mentally, over and over again, that that is actually a good idea, a valid use of my time, and the actual goal is…weird. Realizing that Saturday’s last mile was going to be my middle mile during the half marathon in eight weeks was also quite the rude perspective shift!

Thursday was the first “race pace” run. A mile warm up, a mile cool down, a race pace mile sandwiched in the middle. (Hold the mayo.) (Yes, I’m a dad, have I mentioned that yet?) I’d set a minute-long pace range that I wanted to maintain for that middle mile that was meant to feel like a stretch while also giving me plenty of leeway to make it feel right. Turns out what felt right was a pace fifteen seconds faster than my target range. It felt good! It felt good to open back up some for the first time since the 5k; it was nice to feel like I hadn’t completely lost all the gains I made during that training period. Now, I really don’t believe the pace I ran Thursday was something I could actually maintain for 13 (and an oh and a point and a one-zero) miles; I mean, maybe it is, maybe I’m holding myself back, I know I’m perpetually concerned about over-doing it. (As my wife has put it, “Darby is very aware of his limits.") I don’t know. Either way, I do like those fast-but-not-absurd runs, and I’ve missed them since finishing the 5k training. Having that variety in the week is fun, a little spicy. I think I can safely slide my original target pace range forward by about 30 seconds. We’ll see what happens.

Tuesday night’s easy run continued the trend out of the previous week of my easy pace naturally starting to lift; it felt more like the race pace I expected to do on Thursday night (which probably translated to me pushing that mile faster on Thursday). I think I was running off some stress, too. Either way: faster than expected. Not the third-in-a-row ultra-low-heart-rate-Tuesday-run in a row I was on the lookout for, which is fine.

Looking ahead, things definitely actually for-real-real get interesting the next three weeks. I add a mile a week to the long runs each week (three weeks of new longest runs ever!), and a half mile a week to the race pace segment on Thursdays; Tuesdays will lock in at four miles for a while. Plus I’m pulling all my runs forward a day for the next two weeks, due to some weekend scheduling conflicts. Fingers crossed, that’s not a recipe for disaster.
items.content_text:
I‚Äôd flagged this week as the start of my build phase, but now I think it was maybe my last ‚Äúgimme‚Äù week‚Äîthere wasn't anything in the plan I haven't done before and it was mostly a question of doing it *now* as proof that I could be ready in time for what comes next. So I guess I'll call it a transition week?

My long run on Saturday was seven miles. I've done seven before, a handful of times, and I felt comfortable taking it on this time, even keeping an average pace a notch faster than last week‚Äôs six miler. The weather didn't hurt‚Äîpicture-perfect for running, overcast, low 60s, some breeze. In the past every time I've hit this kind of distance I think I've started to realize just how much the long run game is a mental one as it is a physical one. Running at a comfortable pace means feeling like I could, theoretically, physically do it forever; convincing myself, mentally, over and over again, that that is actually a good idea, a valid use of my time, *and* the actual goal is...weird. Realizing that Saturday's *last* mile was going to be my *middle* mile during the half marathon in eight weeks was also quite the rude perspective shift!

Thursday was the first "race pace" run. A mile warm up, a mile cool down, a race pace mile sandwiched in the middle. (Hold the mayo.) (Yes, I'm a dad, have I mentioned that yet?) I'd set a minute-long pace range that I wanted to maintain for that middle mile that was meant to feel like a stretch while also giving me plenty of leeway to make it feel right. Turns out what felt right was a pace fifteen seconds *faster* than my target range. It felt good! (As my wife has put it, "Darby is very aware of his limits.") I don't know. Either way, I do like those fast-but-not-absurd runs, and I've missed them since finishing the 5k training. Having that variety in the week is fun, a little spicy. I think I can safely slide my original target pace range forward by about 30 seconds. We'll see what happens.

Looking ahead, things definitely actually for-*real*-real get interesting the next three weeks. I add a mile a week to the long runs each week (three weeks of new longest runs ever!), and a half mile a week to the race pace segment on Thursdays; Tuesdays will lock in at four miles for a while. Plus I'm pulling all my runs forward a day for the next two weeks, due to some weekend scheduling conflicts. Fingers crossed, that's not a recipe for disaster.

items.title: Week three running report üèÉ
items.content_html:
When I was setting up this training plan, I had mentally flagged this week not as a do-or-die week, but maybe as a sort of‚Ä¶do-or-seriously-reassess-my-life-choices week. All three runs were longer this week, taking me up to 14.5 miles; nothing too far outside my comfort zone yet, but it was going to be a big jump over last week‚Äôs 12.

The good news is, this week was‚Ä¶fairly uneventful! I feel like I‚Äôm relaxing into and enjoying the easy runs; my pace has been way below what I know I‚Äôm capable of, and I love it. After doing the speed thing earlier this year, running easy feels so pleasant. If I lost all interest in pushing my boundaries, I think I could happily repeat a week like this one for as long as my body wants to hold up.

The most newsworthy run was my 3.5 mile Tuesday run, which was my second shockingly low heart rate Tuesday run in a row. Either my watch glitched twice in a row, or I‚Äôm figuring out the zone two thing when I‚Äôm at my most well-rested. If I make it three in a row I‚Äôll start to think I‚Äôm actually on to something. The Thursday five miler was smooth sailing; I‚Äôve done pretty well in the heat this year, but yeah, the cooler night temperatures are making me happy. Despite shifting into the warmer afternoon today for six miles, I didn‚Äôt have any trouble getting through it, and even managed to clock my fastest pace for the week. Still slow! Still easy! But I‚Äôd be lying if I said it didn‚Äôt feel good to lop a few seconds off my pace without feeling like I was punishing myself in the process.

Looking ahead to week four, I‚Äôll run less total mileage, but I‚Äôll start introducing ‚Äúrace pace‚Äù runs on Thursdays. My plan for those miles right now (well, mile, this week‚Äîone race pace mile, between a warm up and cool down mile) is just to try to run a little faster than I have been lately; still trying to keep it completely doable, but a notch more intense. I‚Äôm giving myself a lot of latitude to experiment, to see what feels good and maintainable, while also knowing I‚Äôm not actually committing myself to running those paces on race day. I think it will be easier to figure out what I‚Äôm doing with those runs once I get a few behind me.

items.title: Week two running report üèÉ
items.content_html:
Not a bad week!

The three miler on Tuesday was weird. I knew I wanted to keep it light after the slugfest that was last Saturday, but‚Ä¶the maximum heart rate my watch reported at the end had to be an error. Was I even moving? Pace felt right, though, slow even for a generally slow runner like me, and I really didn‚Äôt feel even the slightest bit winded at the end of it, so‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know. I‚Äôd like to try to do that again, whatever it is I did!

Thursday felt more typical. It also felt really good. Pace averaged out down under 11/min which is my current rough (and evolving) target for the half. It just felt like a really good run, like exactly the kind of run I hope to maintain for the half. Too soon to tell if that‚Äôs optimistic or not yet.

Saturday‚Äôs five miler I wound up running much earlier in the day than I usually do which mostly means it felt like I had to work for it a bit more than usual. But it was much smoother than last weekend‚Äôs four miler‚Äînever felt like I had to quit or stop, caught myself a couple times feeling like I was maybe starting to ramp up too much and started figuring out how to deliberately slow down a bit to compensate. (Also a good sign, I didn‚Äôt feel completely wiped out for the very long day of family activities I immediately transitioned to post-run.)

Overall this week felt like what I needed; both further cementing a healthy base and also recovering from the rough run last weekend. Which is the kind of thing that really only comes with the perspective of having been doing a thing for a while‚Äîonce upon a time a crummy run meant I was a total failure and all my progress was lost and also I‚Äôm a huge fraud. Now it‚Äôs more just a bump in the road of a much longer game. Not that I don‚Äôt beat myself up for it, just‚Ä¶not as much.

The next two weeks I‚Äôve felt for a while are going to be‚Ä¶interesting? Bellwethers? Things ramp up this week, all three runs are longer than the previous weeks‚Äô counterparts, with a long 5 miler on Thursday and a 6 miler on Saturday. The following week mileage drops a bit for a bit but only because of the transition to race pace runs on Thursdays. It‚Äôs going to get interesting. And educational.

items.title: Week one running report üèÉ
items.content_html:
One week into the half marathon training plan. Still feel like I‚Äôm trying to get back into the swing of things, trying to relearn how to actually keep easy runs‚Ä¶easy.

The first two runs were pretty solid. I don‚Äôt think my knee is giving me any real trouble now.

Saturday‚Äôs four miler was one of my uglier runs, though; had to stop once or twice to get my heart rate back down because I could feel myself redlining. It was far warmer outside than I‚Äôd anticipated, which might have been part of the problem.

So that wasn‚Äôt ideal but the good takeaway was that‚Äîin the past when I‚Äôve stopped like that I‚Äôve typically struggled to keep going at all after; this time I did run all the miles. So that was an interesting development.

Also took a new set of shoes out for the first time, switching from my New Balance 860s to the Asics GT-2000s. I‚Äôve been feeling like I‚Äôve been landing hard in the 860s and felt like it was a good time to try something new after 3 years. One I got going I did like the feel of the Asics. We‚Äôll see how they do over the next week.

items.title: First impressions of the PlayStation 5  üéÆ
items.content_html:
I’ve had two nights with the PlayStation 5. Not coincidentally, I’ve also recently had two utterly and completely blown bedtimes. And I have thoughts!

I’ve heard about the adaptive triggers on the new controllers for a while now but I had no idea what any of it meant until I actually I booted up the Astro’s Playroom demo game and actually felt them kick in. It’s maybe weird to admit this, but it felt like a bit of a jaw-drop moment. I didn’t really know that controllers themselves could still be developed in new and interesting ways. I don’t know how much there is to be done with this, maybe it’s just a weird gimmick, but it feels like a gimmick I would very much miss were it to stop being a thing.

I took the Demon’s Souls remake for a brief spin, just through the intro tutorial and a tiny bit into wandering around the nexus. I played the heck out of the original back in the day and I’m sure I have an incredibly nostalgic view of how good that game looked on the PS3. I imagine if I loaded it up today, it would still look good, I mean it would feel more like a modern game than anything on a PS1 would feel, but it couldn’t look or feel as good as I remember it being. The PS5 remake, though…it looks like my memory of the original. It’s somehow more real than my rose-tinted memory. It made me feel like I was having the kind of disorienting, out-of-time experience that could probably only be represented by an incredibly specific 23 syllable German word. I’m looking forward to spending at least a little more time there.

From there I wanted to try something new and exclusive so I’m taking Returnal for a spin. I’ve been dipping back into Dead Cells again recently on my iPad so this sort of rogue-like system has been top of mind lately‚Äîit’s kind of theoretically perfect for how I play games these days, anyways. Also, Returnal comes from Housemarque, which was responsible for Resogun, probably one of my top ten favorite games ever. So, I mean, it’s an instant gotta-try game. I’m telling myself I’m not going to get locked into any one game out of the gate here, as I don’t have much game-playing time at my disposal, and I want to sample broadly to see what’s what out there, but darn it if after my first couple cycles through the game if I’m not completely hooked on the story, the setting, the look, and the overall feel. It is so absurdly smooth; I’m not prone to motion sickness in games, but oh, sometimes, jumping off a ledge, I can’t help but kind of feel my inner ear start to tell me that hey that ground sure is coming up at you real hard and fast right now.

Still, between these two games there’s definitely a sense of…like I said, the PS3 is closer to a PS5 than a PS1 is to a PS3; this feels like a more powerful iteration of something familiar, not a completely new thing entirely. But…what a compelling iteration it is. I love the Nintendo Switch and I love the games I’m playing on that with my two boys; I mean, Breath of the Wild is so far beyond the hype its silly. I definitely have a few other gaming itches though that I think the PS5 is going to scratch.

One dumb complaint, though: the system interface feels crazy. Maybe they just nailed it with the PS4 interface, but I feel like I’m still trying to wrap my head around what’s available when and what these different hidden layers are and…yeah. I’ll get used to it, I don’t hate it, and maybe it’ll get better if I learn what I can (and should) turn off, but right now it feels like just a bit too much.

I'll get used to it, I don't hate it, and maybe it'll get better if I learn what I can (and should) turn off, but right now it feels like just a bit too much.

items.title: My (current, highly malleable) half-marathon plan üèÉ
items.content_html:
I’ve been thinking about trying a half marathon‚Äîand, yes, a full marathon‚Äîfor a while now. Now, I’m actually planning on going after my first half marathon at the Fall Classic in Cleveland on November 22.

Why now? I’ve been running for three years now, pretty consistently for the last year, and I still like it, I want to keep doing it, and I think I’m in a good position to go for it. Coming off the 5k in July I know that having a challenge like that in front of me helps put the day-to-day activity into a framework that helps me keep my interest levels up. Also, I’m 44, and while I know I’ve got plenty of potential running years ahead of me should I choose to accept them, I also know I’m not getting any younger, so if I’ve got even a flicker of interest in it, now’s probably the time to go for it.

I will also say that my goals here are all very soft. I know well that anything from cataclysmic injury to flagging interest in the face of the demanding commitment could derail the whole process and that’s fine. If I make it, I want it to feel incredible, and if I don’t, I want to remember that I’m still running and have run more miles in this lifetime than I may ever have expected I would.

All that said, my ultimate goal, of course, is to tackle a full marathon. I’ve been toying with some plans for a bit now and I think my best bet is start off with a half marathon in November, another in May 2023, and a third in November 2023, before moving on to the full marathon in May 2024. Assuming I’m still healthy! And happy! And that there’s still land to run on that hasn’t been covered by the sea. I think this gives me the chance to build up my confidence and experiment with training approaches and intensities, while still pacing things out in a way so that it stays fun. I don’t need to rush it and make myself miserable, but I don’t want the big goal to be total vaporware.

For this first half marathon, my only goal right now is to run the whole thing without needing walking breaks. I don’t want to set a firm time goal, though I’m guessing I could land it somewhere between 2:15 and 2:30, if I can maintain a healthy pace for the duration. That said, I took walking breaks during my first 5k in 2019, and during my first 10k earlier this year, and even if I’m running like a dream in the weeks leading up to the half marathon, I know there’s a swell chance race-day nerves will kick in and I’ll wind up coming out hot and I’ll need to compensate later. Which will be perfectly fine‚Äîall the more reason for giving myself at least three attempts at the half distance before going on to full as I work on figuring out how to tame that tendency.

For my training schedule, I’m going somewhat softly this first time, more softly in some ways than I did for the 5k in July. I’m taking a hybrid of this beginner’s plan and this advanced beginer’s plan. I’m taking the slightly more aggressive cadence of the advanced beginner’s plan for the Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday runs, but I’m swapping out the Sunday easy run in favor of cross-training, as suggested by the beginner’s plan.

I’m going with the higher-mileage plan just because because I feel like I can do it, and that those few extra miles each week will help me feel more confident going into the race. Generally the miles will be easier miles than I did training for the 5k‚Äîlike, no hard interval runs, this time out, and my “race pace” runs I think will be less intense than my threshhold runs from the 5k training plan. Mostly I want to continue educating my body about what my “next gear” feels like, to try to get some better sense of what sustainable and potential trouble each feel like. Honestly, pace in general is a huge question mark for me, right now, which is all the more reason to treat this first attempt as an educational experiment.

As for the extra cross-training day on Sundays, while I was running four days a week training for the 5k, while I’m really excited to know I can do that, I kind of want to keep that in reserve for next time. If this first round goes well, introducing the fourth day again next time should be an easy way to help me improve from there. I do also wonder if it was maybe a shade too much, what with including hard intervals and fairly hard threshhold runs in the mix. I’m still working my confidence back up after the mild knee injury I developed during the race and I’m not looking to aggravate that just yet. So aside from just, you know, taking it easy on my joints, I’ve also started getting out on my bicycles again, which has felt really nice, and I’m happy to use cross-training as an excuse to keep putting some easy miles in on the wheels.

All that said, I can’t lie‚ÄîI’m certainly already second-guessing myself, here. Was it a mistake to tell everyone so early that I’m trying this? Is it a mistakle to try this at all? Is this actually already happening, is this real, am I really doing my first official training runs this week? I guess there’s only one way to answer these questions.

items.title: Post race thoughts üèÉ
items.content_html:
First of all: I did the thing.

I did the thing!

That‚Äôs it. That‚Äôs the post-race thought.

As for my thoughts about the thought…

Before this, any time I’ve raced, it’s just been to finish, to cross the finish line. This was the first time I‚Äôve trained and raced with a specific time goal. I’m glad I went through this experiment, and not just because the training pushed me to crush my goal time. I feel like I learned a lot from it, about my range and capabilities as a runner; the effort made me stronger, the edges of my comfort zones pushed back a a couple notches, at least. And of course it kept me on track to keep running through the first hot part of summer.

Of course, ultimately crushing the goal time was like throwing a perfect cherry on top of the sundae…and then throwing an entire second sundae on top of that. All I needed to do to feel succesful was to beat my goal time by at least one second. To come in around three minutes under that time was right up there at the top end of my most optimistic, pie-in-the-sky, head-in-the-cloud secret goals.

My strategy for the run itself was to try to just know that I could do it, that I‚Äôd trained hard enough that I could just let my race day adrenaline do its thing. I pictured myself keeping things smooth but swift for the first two or so miles, so that I’d be able to go all-out the last half-mile, but of course, my race day nerves had other plans, and I did almost the opposite of that, with a fast, hard first mile, and a second mile that wasn’t too far off.

After that…I knew I was running fast and hard, but I didn’t really know by how much. (I’d made the conscious choice not to check my watch at all during the run, because I didn’t want to psych myself out mid-race.) Rounding mile two I knew getting to the end was going to be as much a mental game as a physical one (oh, but it was still deeply, intensely physical!). Telling myself that whole last mile that I didn‚Äôt need to stop, that it wasn’t time to stop yet, that I didn‚Äôt even want to stop, despite all the extremely hard and compelling evidence my body was throwing at me with each breath, was pretty much everything.

Suffice it to say, that planned last half mile kick-up wasn’t in the cards.. I knew I was already leaving everything out there I could, and the only thing left was to dig deep and keep going. Overall, my last mile was my slowest of the three, but the funny thing in retrospect is, is that it was still one of the three fastest complete miles I’ve run maybe ever. “Slowing down” to what was still a ridiculously fast mile, for me? Priceless.

It’s funny to think about now, but at the time, it really felt like time and space were starting todo really weird things that final stretch. That last half mile straight-away up Belle Ave grew longer the further away from Lake Erie I ran. Someone kept moving the train tracks that crossed the mid-point kept moving away from me. The road was in fact rising to meet me…by becoming a mountain directly in front of my face.

And then somewhere past the tracks‚Äîactually, it’s been days since the race and I’m still not convinced I’ve reached those tracks yet, but I digress‚Äîamid the noise of the street festival past the finish line and the folks cheering for the runners alongside the course‚Äîthe cheers of strangers are, truly, gifts‚Äîthere was a guy walking down the sidewalk reading numbers out loud off his phone, twenty-six something, twenty-six something plus one, twenty-six something plus two, and time really did actually slow down for a moment, and I slipped out of my body, and I processed this information, and I realized that I wasn‚Äôt just about to reach my goal‚Äîthis big, dumb, stupid, pointless goal I‚Äôd set for myself two months earlier, that I’d been quietly obsessing over for eight weeks‚Äîbut that I was about to obliterate it, and that realization slammed be back down into my body, and I somehow ran harder.

I may never run like that again. But to feel the something else that lies just below the nothing left briefly take over? To feel that even once was a privilege and a delight. And then going from that to crossing the finish line, running straight into my family‚Äîmy poor family, having my sweat-drenched, hyperventilating form collapsing all over them‚Äîwas just perfect.
